etymologies: Middle English: from Old French supposer, from Latin supponere (from sub- ‘from below’ + ponere ‘to place’), but influenced by Latin suppositus ‘set under’ and Old French poser ‘to place’

definitions: assume that something is the case on the basis of evidence or probability but without proof or certain knowledge

examples.text: I suppose I got there about half past eleven

shortDefinitions: think or assume that something is true or probable but lack proof

definitions: used to make a suggestion or a hesitant admission

examples.text: suppose we leave this to the police
I'm quite a good actress, I suppose

shortDefinitions: used to make suggestion or hesitant admission

definitions: used to introduce a hypothesis and trace or ask about what follows from it

examples.text: suppose he had been murdered—what then?

shortDefinitions: used to introduce hypothesis and imagine its development

definitions: (of a theory or argument) assume or require that something is the case as a precondition

examples.text: the procedure supposes that a will has already been proved
the theory supposes a predisposition to interpret utterances

shortDefinitions: assume or require that something is case as precondition

definitions: believe to exist or to possess a specified characteristic

examples.text: he supposed the girl to be about twelve

shortDefinitions: believe to exist or to possess specified characteristic

definitions: be required to do something because of the position one is in or an agreement one has made

examples.text: I'm supposed to be meeting someone at the airport

shortDefinitions: be required to do something because of position one is in or agreement one has made

examples.text: I shouldn't have been in the kitchen—I'm not supposed to go in there
